- **Yann LeCun** (Meta) [argued forcefully](/?date=2026-01-26&category=social#item-98334b43d494) that auto-regressive LLMs don't truly reason or plan, calling token-based search inefficient compared to latent-space reasoning
- **Geoffrey Hinton** [urged politicians](/?date=2026-01-26&category=social#item-003818aff5c0) to take AI regulation seriously before dismissing it as interference with innovation

items.content:
@deanwball @neqyve @ThomasRodskog No. I'm saying several things but not that.
I'm saying 
1. ***auto-regressive*** LLMs don't reason and don't plan
2. LLMs with token sequence search bolted on top can inefficiently perform reasoning for domain where reasoning can be done in token space (essentially math and code)
3. Actual planning and reasoning requires a search over answers/outputs (by energy minimization). This (a) requires a ***world model*** (LLMs are not it), and (b) is much better done by optimization in continuous space than through combinatorial search in discrete token sequence space.
4. World models that apply to real-world data cannot use generative architectures like LLMs. Because the real world is too messy, noisy, and unpredictable.

I'm saying

3. Actual planning and reasoning requires a search over answers/outputs (by energy minimization). This (a) requires a *world model* (LLMs are not it), and (b) is much better done by optimization in continuous space than through combinatorial search in discrete token sequence space.

4. World models that apply to real-world data cannot use generative architectures like LLMs. Because the real world is too messy, noisy, and unpredictable.

items.title:
Claude is great at coding. Like really, really good, compared to using a regular LLM like Gemini.

T...
items.content:
Claude is great at coding. Like really, really good, compared to using a regular LLM like Gemini.

There's only one issue with it. Because it never sees the full code of the app but uses grep search for relevant code snippets, it's myopic.

If grep returns a fragment of code similar to the bug description, it often doesn't look further and fixes an irrelevant part of the app or answers a question based on these fragments found by grep.

So, as the codebase grows, it becomes important for the user to know the codebase. Otherwise, Claude will reinvent the bicycle over and over again, creating duplicate implementations for the same functionalities in different places in the app.

This issue is probably fixable with additional finetuning, but right now this is how it works.
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: Andriy Burkov analyzes Claude's coding strengths and key limitation: myopic grep-based code search leads to duplicate implementations and irrelevant fixes as codebases grow.
items.reasoning: ML author providing practical technical critique of Claude Code's architecture with high engagement (104k views). Important for practitioners using agentic coding tools.
items.summary_html: Andriy Burkov analyzes Claude's coding strengths and key limitation: myopic grep-based code search leads to duplicate implementations and irrelevant fixes as codebases grow.
items.content_html:
Claude is great at coding. Like really, really good, compared to using a regular LLM like Gemini.

There's only one issue with it. Because it never sees the full code of the app but uses grep search for relevant code snippets, it's myopic.

If grep returns a fragment of code similar to the bug description, it often doesn't look further and fixes an irrelevant part of the app or answers a question based on these fragments found by grep.

So, as the codebase grows, it becomes important for the user to know the codebase. Otherwise, Claude will reinvent the bicycle over and over again, creating duplicate implementations for the same functionalities in different places in the app.

This issue is probably fixable with additional finetuning, but right now this is how it works.

items.title: Exciting addition to the RLHF Book on my DGX Spark arc is a bunch of single GPU, tinkering scripts f...
items.content:
Exciting addition to the RLHF Book on my DGX Spark arc is a bunch of single GPU, tinkering scripts for minimal examples of RL, reward models, etc. (and DPO like algorithms soon).

Right now has REINFORCE, RLOO, PPO, GRPO, Dr. GRPO, GSPO, CISPO, standard reward model, PRM, ORM.

H/t to Zafir Stojanovski an independent researcher for doing a lot of the groundwork.

Would really welcome issues, contributions, and suggestions as we build the RLHF book as a more central home for learning about post-training. I have plans for a lecture series later this year.

items.title:
‚ú® Today I rebuilt üèîÔ∏è AltaVista Search, the main search engine before Google existed

The problem: if...
items.content:
‚ú® Today I rebuilt üèîÔ∏è AltaVista Search, the main search engine before Google existed

The problem: if you press the üîçSearch button in MSIE4 it'll open a sidebar with AltaVista in it that opens:

http:// home . microsoft . com/search/search.asp

But that URL doesn't resolve anymore of course, so how do I make this work?

I asked Claude Code and built a Dnsmasq DNS server that routes all regular DNS queries to Cloudflare but for home . microsoft . com it hijacks it and sends it to my own server

Then I let Nginx respond to that doamin and show the Altavista Search sidebar, I had to rebuild the design from a video on YouTube because I couldn't find any actual archeological remains of it anymore

Also Altavista Search of course doesn't exist anymore so it can't respond to queries either so I use a SERP API to query search results from Google and display them instead

This is stuff I wouldn't even be close to doing before AI, I'd have no idea how to configure Dnsmasq to spoof queries like this

The search engine results are proxied via my HTTP proxy so MSIE4 can open most sites (because old browsers don't support HTTPS and most JS!)

items.summary: Pieter Levels rebuilt AltaVista Search using Claude Code, implementing DNS spoofing with Dnsmasq and HTTP proxy for legacy browser compatibility - tasks he says were impossible before AI

items.title:
Inside a United States robotics factory. @maticrobots 

This is part two. Part I is here: https://t....
items.content:
Inside a United States robotics factory. @maticrobots 

This is part two. Part I is here: https://t.co/OizbiUaD8W

Some things that I learned.

1. They have a robot that they use to calibrate the cameras. The motors in it fail every month or so. This is a $40,000 robot that is an industrial arm. That tells me that humanoids have a long time before we'll see them be extremely reliable.

2. A bag supplier changed the glue they use, causing the robots to fail Q&A. They are fixing the bags, but shows a very cheap part of the robot can take down the line and cause major new costs and rework.

3. They are constrained by space. Soon will be moving into a new building. Innovation in manufacturing means doing a lot of work in a small space.

4. As I watched people work I imagined if a humanoid could do a single job. Not anytime soon. We haven't seen any humanoid even close to being able to handle one of these people's jobs.

Thanks @navneetdalal for giving me a tour and letting me turn on my 360-degree camera, which captures everything. Most factories don't allow that.

items.title: @ArmoredOptimist @xai Answering a question whose answer you've learned by heart is very different fr...
items.author: @ylecun
items.summary: LeCun argues that LLMs answering learned questions differs from understanding underlying reality - the key test is whether systems can handle novel question types.

items.content_html:
@ArmoredOptimist @xai Answering a question whose answer you've learned by heart is very different from understanding the underlying reality.

Given any question, an LLM can be trained to answer it correctly.

The question is whether a system can answer a question of a type it's never faced before.

items.content:
I'm having @blevlabs' AI analyze what's going on in Minneapolis and even it lays out how bad things are getting. Be back in a bit with what it teaches me. 

By the way, his AI (a cognitive architecture) is way better at analyzing these than Grok is. Grok can't read my lists. 

Pulling down 4,000 posts from my news lists (which are the best for watching situations like what's going on) costs me about $25. Then running the Braygents to write reports doubles that (it's only available right now for enterprises).

When I was a student in journalism school I dreamed about having an @AP wire machine in my home. 

This is way better. 

Oh, and the billionaires? Yeah, they aren't leading here. The AI can see that too. So can the humans. 

Which is why I am having AI analyze the news so that they can get completely up to date on the various points of view before they act.

Of course, the billionaires should already have a cognitive architecture so they can run the same. 

My lists are key: https://t.co/9eRY65x3IQ

This is a super power for using X. 

Be back in a few.

items.title: In transformers, self-attention layers process sequences without built-in notions of order, so posit...
items.content:
In transformers, self-attention layers process sequences without built-in notions of order, so positional embeddings‚Äîvectors added to token representations to encode their positions‚Äîare used to provide that information.

Rotary positional embeddings, or RoPE, a common type that applies rotations to queries and keys in attention, turn out to accelerate training by giving gradient descent a helpful starting bias that makes convergence happen faster, as shown through analysis of attention patterns and gradients.

At the same time, keeping RoPE after training restricts the model from handling sequences longer than its original context length without further adjustments, because the rotations become unfamiliar at new positions.

Removing these embeddings post-training and running a short recalibration at the original length lets the model adapt while preserving its short-context abilities, enabling it to work on much longer inputs immediately, with experiments across model scales up to billions of parameters demonstrating better retrieval and perplexity than standard scaling techniques.

Read with an AI tutor: https://t.co/thPWb1o3WO

Read alone: https://t.co/ULuu3lJBSY
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: Burkov explains RoPE (Rotary Position Embeddings) in transformers - how they accelerate training but limit context length, and how removing them post-training enables longer contexts.
items.reasoning: Technical educational content about transformer architecture from respected ML author. Valuable for practitioners understanding model internals.
items.summary_html: Burkov explains RoPE (Rotary Position Embeddings) in transformers - how they accelerate training but limit context length, and how removing them post-training enables longer contexts.
items.content_html:
In transformers, self-attention layers process sequences without built-in notions of order, so positional embeddings‚Äîvectors added to token representations to encode their positions‚Äîare used to provide that information.

Rotary positional embeddings, or RoPE, a common type that applies rotations to queries and keys in attention, turn out to accelerate training by giving gradient descent a helpful starting bias that makes convergence happen faster, as shown through analysis of attention patterns and gradients.

At the same time, keeping RoPE after training restricts the model from handling sequences longer than its original context length without further adjustments, because the rotations become unfamiliar at new positions.

items.title:
If I were a junior developer today, I would speedrun learning the fundamentals.

Things like SOLID, ...
items.content:
If I were a junior developer today, I would speedrun learning the fundamentals.

Things like SOLID,  clean code, clean architecture, and a bit of algo/puzzle solving for logical thinking (leetcode)

Then I would maximize using AI, but actually read the generated code and understand it. Talk to AI or a senior dev if you have any questions.

Learning from open source is also a great way to upgrade your skills quickly.

I think AI accelerates the learning process and raises the level of what a junior-level engineer can do.

The expectations for a junior dev role will be much higher than they were 3 years ago. But devs are smart, they can learn anything.

Only people who are too comfortable with their level and stopped learning will risk getting replaced and forced to learn the new way.

I think AI accelerates the learning process and raises the level of what a junior-level engineer can do.

The expectations for a junior dev role will be much higher than they were 3 years ago. But devs are smart, they can learn anything.

Only people who are too comfortable with their level and stopped learning will risk getting replaced and forced to learn the new way.

items.title:
@ThomasRodskog @deanwball There is nothing wrong with this slide.
It talks about ***auto-regressive ...
items.content:
@ThomasRodskog @deanwball There is nothing wrong with this slide.
It talks about ***auto-regressive token prediction***
Reasoning models produce multiple token sequences and ***search*** for a good one, as evaluated by a separate model.
That no longer constitutes strict auto-regressive token prediction.

In my talks, I argue that reasoning should be performed by search/optimization.
That's the whole idea of energy-based models, which I've been advocating for for 20 years.
Token sequence selection is a *very primitive* and super-inefficient form of reasoning-by-search.
It works ok for math and code, but for almost nothing else.
items.author: @ylecun
items.summary: LeCun argues reasoning models that search over multiple token sequences are no longer strict auto-regressive prediction - this is primitive, inefficient reasoning-by-search that only works for math/code.
items.reasoning: Technical elaboration on LeCun's position about reasoning architectures. Important context for AI architecture debates.
items.summary_html: LeCun argues reasoning models that search over multiple token sequences are no longer strict auto-regressive prediction - this is primitive, inefficient reasoning-by-search that only works for math/code.

@ThomasRodskog @deanwball There is nothing wrong with this slide.

It talks about *auto-regressive token prediction*

Reasoning models produce multiple token sequences and *search* for a good one, as evaluated by a separate model.

That no longer constitutes strict auto-regressive token prediction.

In my talks, I argue that reasoning should be performed by search/optimization.

That's the whole idea of energy-based models, which I've been advocating for for 20 years.

Token sequence selection is a *very primitive* and super-inefficient form of reasoning-by-search.

It works ok for math and code, but for almost nothing else.

items.title:
@strikerglows ah good question. to help answer this: 

first, what llamasheets does is transform an ...
items.content:
@strikerglows ah good question. to help answer this: 

first, what llamasheets does is transform an excel sheet into segmented 2d tables, through an API 

second, if you don't want to use llamasheets, you could always have some generalized reasoning agent with code interpreter as a baseline to interpret/edit excel files (basically claude over excel). it's a strong baseline, but the agent has to write a bunch of code to understand the tables, and oftentimes write a bunch of code to replicate what llama-sheets is doing already. 

using llama-sheets gives a few advantages:
- it creates a nicer format if you're building some RAG chatbot. putting it in 2d tables allows your agent to query the data with text-to-sql, which seems easier than writing a ton of code
- it creates a nicer format if you're writing deterministic scripts to then ETL the extracted tables into some downstream storage system. claude + code interpreter can do this too, but it'll take longer, probably burn more tokens, and may be less accurate
- you can still use claude/general reasoning agent on top of the extracted 2d tables, *along* with a general code interpreter. the advantage is that the coding agent has to do less work trying to understand the excel sheet, or doing the work that llama-sheets is doing already. 

that said, llama-sheets is very much in beta, so if you have feedback or it's not working very well let us know! here's some docs to get started: https://t.co/1VKR9JUFA9
items.author: @jerryjliu0
items.summary: Jerry Liu explains LlamaSheets transforms Excel into segmented 2D tables for easier RAG/text-to-SQL integration, comparing to baseline Claude+code interpreter approach
items.reasoning: Detailed technical explanation of LlamaIndex product from founder. Useful for understanding structured data handling in AI pipelines.
items.summary_html: Jerry Liu explains LlamaSheets transforms Excel into segmented 2D tables for easier RAG/text-to-SQL integration, comparing to baseline Claude+code interpreter approach

second, if you don't want to use llamasheets, you could always have some generalized reasoning agent with code interpreter as a baseline to interpret/edit excel files (basically claude over excel). it's a strong baseline, but the agent has to write a bunch of code to understand the tables, and oftentimes write a bunch of code to replicate what llama-sheets is doing already.

using llama-sheets gives a few advantages:

  • it creates a nicer format if you're building some RAG chatbot. putting it in 2d tables allows your agent to query the data with text-to-sql, which seems easier than writing a ton of code
  • it creates a nicer format if you're writing deterministic scripts to then ETL the extracted tables into some downstream storage system. claude + code interpreter can do this too, but it'll take longer, probably burn more tokens, and may be less accurate
  • you can still use claude/general reasoning agent on top of the extracted 2d tables, *along* with a general code interpreter. the advantage is that the coding agent has to do less work trying to understand the excel sheet, or doing the work that llama-sheets is doing already.

that said, llama-sheets is very much in beta, so if you have feedback or it's not working very well let us know! here's some docs to get started: https://t.co/1VKR9JUFA9

items.title: Of course, there is a market for juniors. It's just that the definition and expectations changed gre...
items.content:
Of course, there is a market for juniors. It's just that the definition and expectations changed greatly because of AI.

If you graduate today and apply for a junior role, but you only have the skills of a junior who graduated in 2021 (no AI), it's obvious that no one wants you.

From POV of companies, they always want new juniors so that they have future seniors in the future.

items.content: There has always been a very ‚Äúhealthy‚Äù dose of psychopaths in the Valley, one very notable example being the much venerated late cofounder of the fruit company. All frontiers attract such people. But the early years were still characterized by the disproportionate number of people who were in it because they loved the tech and innovation in their own right. That has not been the case any more for at least a decade or two.

items.reasoning: Methodological transparency about AI news analysis approach
items.summary_html: Scobleizer explains methodology: grabbing 1000 posts for recent news focus, acknowledges limitation of not looking at historical context
items.content_html:
@LiveFree_Or_Die Fair enough. I only asked it to grab the last 1,000 posts, which means everything in mine is very recent and focused on today's news. It doesn't look at the historical news or what led up to this (I didn't ask it to show that either).

I was asking: what should tech leaders do right now?

I was trying to get a good idea of what is actually happening on X right now as well. This is a good blind spot that someone who was going to do this professionally would need to take into account: they would need to ask deeper questions and perhaps pay for more API calls to grab more than 1,000 posts from each list.

items.title: Believe or not, the international gold standard for investigating potentially unlawful deaths where ...
items.content:
Believe or not, the international gold standard for investigating potentially unlawful deaths where state involvement is suspected is called the "Minnesota Protocol".

It's named like because it was developed by the Minnesota Lawyers International Human Rights Committee, in a very different and more human time (the 1990s).

The protocol is built on the principle that the right to life is meaningless if there is no requirement for the state to investigate when that life is taken. It ensures that when someone is killed by police, military, or in state custody, there is a clear, objective path to uncovering the truth and holding the perpetrators accountable. It's basically a handbook for when and how to conduct such investigations.

For an investigation to be credible, the protocol mandates four key pillars: it must be independent (no "police investigating themselves"), prompt (starting before evidence is lost), effective (a genuine search for the truth, not just going through the motions), and transparent (keeping the victim‚Äôs family and the public informed).

Technically, the protocol is a comprehensive manual for forensics and law. It contains detailed guidelines on crime scene management, digital evidence collection, and forensic autopsies, such as tracking bullet trajectories to prove if a victim was shot while surrendering. It even includes specialized procedures for protecting witnesses from state retaliation.

items.title:

Here is how to win, according to the AI.

***SPOI...
items.content:
And of course the main character's name is Elara.

Here is how to win, according to the AI.

***SPOILERS***
Walkthrough: The Enchanted Lighthouse

  Phase 1: Gather Basic Items

  south                    ‚Üí Cottage
  take journal             ‚Üí Read for hints
  examine rocking chair    ‚Üí Find cottage key
  take key
  east                     ‚Üí Kitchen
  open drawer              ‚Üí Find knife
  take knife
  open pantry              ‚Üí Find vial
  take vial
  take moonbane
  west                     ‚Üí Cottage

  Phase 2: Garden & Shore Items

  west                     ‚Üí Garden
  use key on shed          ‚Üí Unlocks shed
  take oil
  take bowl
  examine bench            ‚Üí Find locket
  take locket
  scratch angel            ‚Üí Get resin (need knife)
  south                    ‚Üí Rocky Shore
  take rope
  use vial on pools        ‚Üí Collect glowing shells
  combine oil with shells  ‚Üí Creates CELESTIAL OIL ‚úì

  Phase 3: Get the Brass Key (Cave)

  north                    ‚Üí Garden
  west                     ‚Üí Cliffs
  examine bench            ‚Üí Find love letter
  take letter
  east                     ‚Üí Garden
  Wait for "Tide: Low" message (every 10 moves), then:
  south                    ‚Üí Shore
  east                     ‚Üí Cave (only at low tide!)
  talk captain
  take sealed letter
  open sealed letter       ‚Üí Get BRASS KEY ‚úì
  west                     ‚Üí Shore

  Phase 4: Repair the Lens

  north                    ‚Üí Garden
  east                     ‚Üí Cottage
  north                    ‚Üí Lighthouse Base
  up                       ‚Üí Lighthouse Top
  take fragment
  take fragment
  take fragment            ‚Üí All 3 lens pieces
  take cloth
  combine fragments with resin  ‚Üí Assembled lens
  polish lens              ‚Üí LENS REPAIRED ‚úì

  Phase 5: Sacred Spark Ritual

  down                     ‚Üí Lighthouse Base
  south                    ‚Üí Cottage
  west                     ‚Üí Garden
  lower bowl               ‚Üí Ritual at well (need moonbane, bowl, locket, rope)
                           ‚Üí Creates GLOWING LOCKET (Sacred Spark) ‚úì

  Phase 6: Victory!

  east                     ‚Üí Cottage
  north                    ‚Üí Lighthouse Base
  up                       ‚Üí Lighthouse Top
  open mechanism           ‚Üí Use brass key
  light flame              ‚Üí VICTORY!

@paulg Trump is just the trigger.
There are deep historical forces:
The dismantling of the FCC fairness doctrine by Reagan, the resulting emergence of Fox News, conservative talk radio, and other propaganda outlets, the removal of guardrails for the influence of money in politics (e.g. Citizen United), the continuous reduction of taxes on high incomes, the ever-increasing wealth and income inequalities enabled by the above, the stagnation of working class income despite continued increase in productivity (and corporate profits), the total lack of social protection and benefits compared to other developed countries.
People in the middle class and below have been screwed for 40 years and are angry.
They should be angry at Republicans. 
But the Republican party has managed to deflect their anger towards immigrants, non-Christians, non-whites, liberals, LGBT, China, academia, intellectual "elites", scientists, journalists, and non-existent scarecrows like Antifa.

items.title: @frankgoertzen Not an honest question but I'll answer anyway. There are over 75,000 immigrants curre...
items.content: @frankgoertzen Not an honest question but I'll answer anyway. There are over 75,000 immigrants currently in detention in the US, at facilities like "Alligator Alcatraz" which are referred to as "concentration camps" by observers like Amnesty International or the ACLU and in the press of non-US first world countries. Survivors report widespread rapes, beatings, torture, and several cases of personnel killing detainees like in case of Geraldo Lunas Campos a few days ago (look it up). Obviously the large majority of incidents never surface. Over 4,000 people are entirely missing (no records of where they went) after getting checked into the system last year.

items.title: Fun! Fact: when I was in middle school we lived in Minneapolis, a block from Alan Page, a recently r...
items.content:
Fun! Fact: when I was in middle school we lived in Minneapolis, a block from Alan Page, a recently retired famous football player. He was a runner, as was my dad.  My dad told me about him.  He had just finished law school and was now starting his second career as a lawyer eventually becoming a Minnesota Supreme Court justice.  Both of them would run in the dead of winter in Minneapolis, and my dad said he cared about people, so this photo doesn't surprise me.

You can read more about Alan Page here: 

https://t.co/4WALdkwjnB
(Excerpt below) 

Thank you, Alan Page.

items.content:
Remember that social media is inherently performative. People self-censor for a number of reasons, including their image, academic politics, or even safety. 

I try to be pretty authentic but even I'm susceptible. Let's grab a beer if you want to know my unfiltered thoughts.

items.title: Worth point out how unusual it is, on a global scale, to have someone executed on their knees in the...
items.content:
Worth point out how unusual it is, on a global scale, to have someone executed on their knees in the street by a masked paramilitary that only answers to the executive and that operates entirely extra-legally, with total impunity, deployed to wage a terror campaign on a city's population.

It would be unthinkable in a mild dictatorship like Morocco or Thailand. Even Turkey or Kazakhstan doesn't do that. The countries that have seen similar cases are the likes of Iran, Russia, Venezuela, El Salvador, Somalia, North Korea, or the Philippines in the Duterte era. And now the USA.

It's actually a very short list.

items.title:
Exceptionally bad air quality in Western Europe today

Something you don't see that often because us...
items.content:
Exceptionally bad air quality in Western Europe today

Something you don't see that often because usually it's quite clean

The smog is entering the Netherlands and Germany from the East so probably originates from massive coal and wood fire burning in Poland

Similar things happen around the world: in Thailand a lot of the bad air quality comes from crop burning in Myanmar and Singapore has bad air quality issues due to smog from Indonesia

So it's kind of the same as buying a house, you can't choose your neighbors and all you can do is hope they're not using their chimney cause you end up getting gassed

I'm surprised we had to live with it for so long until Grab and Uber arrived.

items.title: In times like this, I try to tune it all out and go back to the most basic principle of human decenc...
items.content:
In times like this, I try to tune it all out and go back to the most basic principle of human decency:

Extend the same love, dignity, and care to others that you seek for yourself.

Today, I find myself with only two choices:

1. Stand with those who cheat, kill, and lie.
2. Stand with those who don't.

This is not complicated.
items.author: @svpino
items.summary: Santiago's ethical/moral statement about human decency and choosing sides

I don't have breakfast usually

Black coffee only

Then after 2-3 hours we usually eat lunch which is usually meat (steak or chicken), with some rice and fruit like blueberries, blackberries, raspberries, banana or sliced apple

Then dinner similar

Very boring diet, very healthy
